en.purpose: To assess and classify the functional capacity of patients with heart failure by determining the level of physical activity they can perform without experiencing symptoms. This classification helps guide treatment plans, monitor disease progression, and evaluate treatment outcomes.
en.use:
Pre-conditions: Used in patients diagnosed with heart failure to evaluate their functional status and severity of symptoms. It is applicable to both chronic and acute heart failure cases.
Usage: The NYHA classification is performed by evaluating the patient's reported symptoms and exercise tolerance. The classification is divided into four classes:

Class I: No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms.

Class II: Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitations, or shortness of breath.

Class III: Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms.

Class IV: Inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms may be present even at rest.

Interpretation: The classification helps physicians determine the severity of the patient's heart failure and tailor interventions accordingly.
en.misuse:
Not to be used for assessment of non-cardiac conditions. The NYHA classification is specific to heart failure and should not be applied to assess other cardiovascular diseases or non-cardiac conditions.
Not to be used as a diagnostic tool. It is used for functional classification and symptom assessment in known heart failure patients, not for diagnosing heart failure itself.

gt0001.text: New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Classification for Heart Failure score
gt0001.description: The New York Heart Association (NYHA) Functional Classification is a clinical tool used to assess the severity of symptoms and the functional limitations in patients with heart failure. It categorizes patients into four classes based on their ability to perform physical activity and the presence of symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations.

gt0004.description: No limitation of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitation or shortness of breath.

gt0037.description: Slight limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, shortness of breath or chest pain.

gt0038.description: Marked limitation of physical activity. Comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitation, shortness of breath or chest pain.

gt0039.description: Symptoms of heart failure at rest. Any physical activity causes further discomfort.

gt0044.description: Patients can perform minimal activities without symptoms, but moderate activities cause them.

gt0045.description: Patients experience symptoms even with very minimal activities, such as moving within their home or performing light tasks.
